description:
Alright alright. It's about time I got this review written. If you want the short version - the best in SF.  Long version - read below.

I fell in love with this little shop about 1 year ago...and I fell hard. When I took my first step through that blue door, I was immediately brought back to my favorite spot in Paris. It's petite but boy do they bring the heat. I can go on and on but if I had to choose one word to differentiate Provender from the 100 other coffee shops in SF it would be: heart. A place that makes you feel at home. The Ferrari brothers do it right. They care about you, what they do and will only give you the absolute best. 

Coffee - If you want to know what a true cappuccino taste like, this is the spot. I swear to you, no one makes better coffee than the baristas here. Fire. 
Now if you need something cold - the maplewood cold brew is one of a kind. Sweetened just right  side note: the Growler is the perfect housewarming gift ;) 

Food - I have a weak spot for pastries so my heart melted when I had a slice of the sesame banana bread - sold. Chocolate chip cookies (currently craving), blackberry poppyseed scone, almond bread, cardamom cake, bacon goat cheese biscuit and now a kardemummbullar...ahhh I love them all! Best bet - get 2-3 to "share."

Now the toast...you have never had toast like this. Avocado toast is what they are known for (rightly so) but don't be afraid to try the smoked trout toast - out of this world. If you're craving something on the sweeter side, the banana almond butter toast is the way to go. 
Recommendation: Go with a friend and split two.

Two words. Egg Samich. Get it. Fluffy and delicious. 

This shop deserves a lot of love. I promise, you'll keep going back for more and will always walk out smiling.
author: Mekenna D.

description:
Day 1: Avocado toast and almond butter toast and sample of the black sesame banana bread.
Day 2: Back for more avocado toast and a full slice of banana bread.

Kinda says it all. Maybe the best avocado toast I've ever had. These folks know what they're doing!
author: Adam B.

description:
Yessss, absolutely delicious avocado toast! The trout toast was also phenomenal. So many powerful flavors and textures uniting in the most delightful way. I honestly cannot choose which of the two I liked more.

As for the avocado toast, they use an entire avocado and the avocados are at the exact right level of ripeness. Hard to describe the flavor properly but if I had to pick two words, it'd be creamy and tangy. I wish I could eat this for breakfast everyday.

Service was a bit slow, it took surprisingly a long time to make something that doesn't really require cooking.

Also, the place itself is tiny, not much room to sit at all. But what little space they have, they make it quite aesthetically pleasing.
author: Jenny W.

description: The best place to grab cappuccino and bite to eat on Potrero Hill! I'd recommend their Fried Egg sandwich which is delicious with aioli. The avocado toast is amazing as well as any of their pastries especially chocolate chip cookie with salt! You can also grab a country bread from Tartine if you want to bring something for dinner that night!
author: Mike J.

description:
My favorite coffee shop in all of San Francisco! You think I'm exaggerating when I say I'm here every morning, but I am here every morning. 

The Experience: You walk into this quaint little shop at the top of Potrero Hill and immediately you're greeted with the aroma of fresh ground coffee beans and fresh pastries. It feels like home. There's little standing room, but on a beautiful day, perch with your coffee outside and lounge on the benches with a book or friends and watch the eclectic locals and large fluffy dogs walk by.

The Magic: Quality local ingredients and an emphasis on fresh everything! The Ferrari Bros who designed and own the coffee shop don't skimp on the details. Every part of the coffee experience is divine: from the beautiful ceramic espresso cups to using Andy Town Coffee (the highest quality coffee beans in the city!) to the beautiful seasonal latte art. Everything feels crafted with attention and love. Sometimes I sit in the shop and watch the fresh avocados come in, or the giant loaves of fresh sourdough from Tartine Manufactory ferried through the door. The prices are steep, but when you account for the fact that every bite you have is brought to life with the highest quality ingredients, the indulgence is worth every bite. 

The Tips:
-- Avocado toast here is $10 but entirely worth it: a touch of Maldon salt flakes, homemade garlic crisps, and dash of spice atop fresh thick sourdough from Tartine. You'll never look at avocado toast the same way again (which to be honest saves your wallet in the long run).
-- If you are lucky, I will not have bought and consumed all the chocolate chip cookies. They're made fresh every morning and to die for!
-- The egg sandwich is something akin to heaven with a perfectly gooey yolk and crisp egg white finish. They introduced it a few weeks ago for their 3-year anniversary!
author: Jessica M.

description:
Vibes 5/5: AMAZING. This coffee shop is so cute and adorable and located on a cute little strip in potrero hill. 

Food 4/5: Andytown coffee, it was okay. But the cups were cute and I appriciate that. 

Service 3.5/5: below par, but they seemed either stress or just unhappy. We all have bad days. 

Would I do back? YESSSS

Ranking for my notes, not for the stars. 
5- Amazing, top of the line- standout 
4- Very good
3- Not good
2- Horrible
1- Very bad
author: Tina L.

description: This is definitely on the pricier side when it comes to coffee but the interior/exterior and taste is so interesting that I've got to give it 5 stars! I didn't get anything to eat but they have several options for sweet and savory treats. The cardamom cake and avo toast look pretty good...I'll be back for sure!
author: Meryam B.

description:
Cute coffee spot. Nice to stop here if you're in the neighborhood, but I wouldn't go out of my way.

They have limited seating so it's more like an order-and-go spot, but they do have benches on the sidewalk. If you need the restroom, you can go to Chez Maman a few doors down.

Their coffee comes in these very homey looking (and somehow comforting) ceramic mugs. 

* Chai Tea Latte - 3 stars
Great texture, but I found it a little lacking in flavor.

* Scone - 3.5 stars
A nice snack, but if I'm being super picky, this was a tad on the dry side.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Good little spot on 18th Street in Portrero Hill. 

The people working here are always personable and seem to know my type of Spotify Playlist. Most mornings it's very R&B and Hip Hop bumping through the speakers, while the guy making Avocado Toast is bobbing his head to the grooves! I'm always there with him, as it's my music genre of choice too. 

Both their coffee drinks and confections are good. This little shop gives a vibe of cafes found in Europe. 

It is pricey, but hey it's not mass produced Peets or Starbucks.
author: Matthew R.

description:
As a lover of hipster toast, I had this place bookmarked for quite some time. The place has a very cute decor although it was a lot smaller than I pictured it. There are a few seats inside for you to eat at and quite a good amount of seating outside although it fills up pretty quickly. Lots of parking in the area which is a plus for San Francisco. I wasn't that impressed with the variety of baked goods that were available but I went during the afternoon so maybe there is more to choose from in the morning. 

I ordered a mocha and the almond butter + banana + honey toast. So first things first, it is expensive. Both items came out to $14 and some change. Now, the toast is quite large so compared to The Mill's toast, it is a bit more substantial. You get 2 really big pieces of bread with toppings. It is pretty filling too in part because of the thick bread. Pretty good but not sure if it is $8 good. I do prefer the brown sugar toast at The Mill when I want something sweet on bread. I did want to try the avocado toast since many people have mentioned it is amazing, but to be honest, I have been making it at home for breakfast daily so I didn't want to eat it back to back. Maybe next time. All in all, I do prefer the toast at The Mill or Trouble Coffee a little bit more although they both do not have avocado toast and Provender is closer to my house. The mocha was good although also not memorable.
author: Cicely T.

description:
I climbed , I ate/drank, I conquered , located on a popular street in beautiful Potrero Hill. I was in search for a "cute cafe" to get some fuel before a busy day of errands. 

First off it's def really cute! The ppl working here were absolutely the best, karaoke-ing while they serve some delicious bites and drinks! 

I shared the avocado toast although I wish I got my own (story of my life) and a maplewood cold brew w/almond milk --- both are the best I've had in SF and while pricey i think the quality is worth it!!

Wish I had more time to hang out outside and enjoy I can't wait to go back!!
author: Hetal P.

description: What a fun place. I live the chill feel in this cafe. Delicious well prepared coffee in very cute mugs, great variety of baked goods and one of the best avocado toast I've had in the bay area - little left to want. We really enjoyed our experience here and the people there were very warm as well. I'll definitely go back!
author: Namrata J.

description:
1- maple cold brew. If you're like me and love maple syrup, you must get this. It's very sweet but it's a nice treat every now and then. I've started putting a little maple syrup in my coffee now bc of Provender!

2- avocado toast... Let me tell you - a whole avocado, toasted tartine country bread (yes), v lemony & garlicky (love), and salty (could use less). Would get again and again
author: Janelle K.

description:
I'm going to make a bold statement and say that the simple Avocado Toast here is the best I've ever had in SF (maybe even in the world; however, that is TBD as it's an ongoing debate among my friends at the moment). 

Let me explain the Avo Toast greatness:
It starts off with a toasted piece of baguette with creamy garlic aioli spread as the base. Then it's layered with freshly sliced whole avocado. Topped off with black sesame seeds, flake salt, crispy garlic, fresh cilantro, and lemon (or lemon+olive oil? not sure yet). 

It sounds simple but the lemon and fresh cilantro flavor cuts through the super creamy avocado and the crunch from the garlic and sesame adds really nice texture. If you're looking for more, then add a sous-vide on top or some bacon. I personally just learned to ask for some chile flakes on top to spice things up. Lastly if you're lucky and get to enjoy your avo toast at the shop, one of them make the toast into a shape of a heart *swoon*

All this paired with a nice cup of coffee just makes my morning. The downside is that it's pretty pricey and the shop is small like most people have mentioned. But I'd still recommend skipping the 2hr line at Plow and heading to Provender for a delicious meal/snack!
author: Kathy L.

description:
Inspired by their feature in Drift Magazine, we went for a visit.  Their maple cold brew is listed among the iconic San Francisco coffee drinks. 

Their coffee is very good, their coffee background comes from their Calabrian roots. 
Also, try their toast with anchovies!
author: Geordie E.

description: Avocado toast. That is all. I don't even drink coffee yet every Sunday here I am to order avocado toast. It's the best I've found anywhere. And yes, maybe it is a millennial thing but it's amazing.
author: Leina K.

description: Perfect day for avocado toast with garlic aioli and cilantro. The banana with almond butter toast is great too. I'd prefer without bananas since I'm not a fan. Since it's a pretty small place, the outdoor seating is perfect to get some sun and read.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Must order: Maplewood cold brew! 

Highlights
- I just found my favorite neighborhood coffee shop that is not a chain and serves up one of the best cold brews in the city! Happy dancing right now, since I'm not always about making the trip out to downtown or the Ferry building to stand in line with tourists or FIDI workers for my go to New Orleans iced coffee at Blue Bottle. There may be some days for that, but there are other days where I simply want to chill and hit up a neighborhood spot that none of the tourists frequent. 
- Literally a hole in the wall with just a few bar stool seats. There is not much more to ask for, it's a nice local discovery.
- Maplewood cold brew, order it! If you love New Orleans iced coffee at Blue Bottle, this one pretty gives it a run for it's money with more of brown sugar hint and slightly sweeter, but the same chicory taste to it. 

Improvements
- None really, I came really early when they first opened on a Tuesday and I got the last cup of Maplewood cold brew. Thank the coffee gods I did not leave empty handed! Not really a laptop setup/working space type of place, but good to grab and go or a chill spot for a little bit if you want to break away from the hustle and bustle of the crazy downtown crowds. 
- Opened at 7:30AM, wish it was a tad earlier, but having this option is already exciting enough and coffee in the morning is all that I need.

Tips
- Street parking only
- They also serve some unique breakfast pastries and avocado toast that I have yet to try.
author: Tracy T.

description:
I discovered Provender when waiting in the never-ending lines on the 18th street brunch power houses in SF. I loved that they had their own selection of amazing snacks and toasts (yes ... even avocado toast), but more so I loved that they had solid coffee.

They don't have much room inside, but the staff is extremely knowledgable. They make a kick ass flat white and if you get there early enough you can snag one of the 4 bar stool seats facing outwards and people watch as you see others rush to places like Plow to get in line.

They have cute benches outside and are very dog friendly as well. The only down side is that they don't do soy anymore, like everyone else in SF :(
author: Lorrie M.

description: Overpriced for what you get bitter coffee and inattentive staff. Expected more from a local shop. Disappointed to say the least.
author: Zoe M.

description:
Opinion of a friend of mine visiting from Williamsburg NYC- "15$ for avocado toast???? Are you kidding me? Hey no wonder all the lamest, smug, rude people I've ever come across in SF seem to frequent this establishment."  OUCH...

I really liked Provender on first impression until I had the worst all around cafe experience of my life. Firstly, the guy behind the counter was really rude when I asked if there was egg on the 15$ avo toast. "Ummmm... no. It's avocado toast. It has avocado on toast." 
I'm apparently the only customer they have had who thinks 15$ for just avocado on toast is a bit excessive. The barista could have simply replied with a pleasant no sir without giving me attitude.

What really irked me and led to a more negative experience was the second big issue per a rude self righteous customer in line behind us commenting about how we had a bag with us that we shouldn't be ordering our coffee with a single use cup "I can't believe you have a big bag and don't have a coffee mug to save using a disposable cup!"  (Lady, maybe you should be complaining to single use coffee cup and 15$ avo toast cafe management and not a first time customer. I'm all about using a reusable cup but keep the comments to yourself you smug &$@*%!!!!!)

Overall, in three visits to this cafe I have had one rude experience with staff and two poor and offensive experiences with patrons. I have taken exception to a few outrageously overpriced items on the menu and don't plan on returning. Shame, I had hoped its proximity to my new home would have made it a regular spot.
author: Ryan M.

description: Dear Lord- this was the best avocado toast I have ever had. Friendly owners. Excellent coffee!
author: Alisha T.

description: Took 10 minutes to just get a cup of tea. I would understand if it took maybe 3-4 minutes but 10 is just ridiculous, especially since we were the only people in there. I don't recommend this place if you have anything to do the rest of your day. You'll just spend half your day in here waiting for a cup of tea.
author: Monica B.

description:
On a sweltering summer day in San Francisco, there ain't no pick-me-up quite like a caffeinated, icy-cool beverage. Bonus points if it comes with a straw.

In the neighborhood and dying of heat, I whipped out my phone and Yelped for the closest bougie coffee joint. Provender caught my eye because of the Maple Cold Brew that kept popping up on reviews. (On the menu, it's actually Maplewood Cold Brew.) Hopefully on such a hot day, they still had some left over. Provender is suitable for just grabbing a cup/pastry and jetting. It's not much cooler inside the store than outside, and there's not much room to sit. Luckily, the Maplewood Cold Brew doesn't take long to order and serve up. It's literally poured into a cup with ice from a pitcher. The quantity you get is not super generous considering you're paying $4 per cup (with ice already in there!), but I had to try their signature menu item at least once.

The Maplewood Cold Brew... with no additions, it's deliciously bittersweet. It's pretty balanced between maple-sweet and black coffee-bitter. Pretty refreshing, without getting too cloying. Messes with your mind long enough to get you to stop thinking about the heat outside, at least. Do they soak actual maplewood in coffee? Do they just mix tons of maple syrup in a bunch of coffee? I could see myself stopping by again for another cup, though it shouldn't be too often, at that price.
author: Jade V.

description: My coworker swears by this place and since we were all working in the city on a nice Friday morning, we decided to come here for our morning coffee. The Maple Cold Brew is so amazing, it's on another level. I like cold brew, not crazy about it, but this one is top notch! The maple is really the wow factor and I've never had cold brew like this. You can really taste the sweetness from the maple, but it's not too much. Cold brew is usually kind of bitter in my opinion, but I didn't experience that at all. I added almond milk with it and oh my god, it's the best! I almost got a vanilla latte, but they don't even offer it! Don't come here to get a basic drink, try their cold brew and you won't regret it!
author: Thy B.

description:
TINY lil spot out in Potrero Hill, but very charming. If you're there on a Wednesday morning, that's street cleaning day.

They partner with Andytown for their batch brew, maybe espresso too (don't quote me on that). Their Maplewood Cold Brew is the thing to get, I have it straight, like a real coffee drinker (jk, kind of... haha) but you have dairy and almond milk at your disposal as well.

Honestly, I haven't had their food, but it looks delicious (and pricey) but I would imagine you get what you pay for.

Everyone who works here is super chill, especially the pretty barista Jackie. She has a dope coffee IG account too coffee.with.jackie, check it out.
author: Aaron C.

description: Small but high quality. They are receptive to requests and remember return customers. Today I ordered a latte and the head barista (?) remembered I wanted it extra hot. I was surprised and delighted when I asked for my cardamom bun (fantastic) and he pulled it out of the warming oven (which I didn't request but made it that much more enjoyable). great start to my day!
author: Alex S.

description:
Great coffee. But the guy serving was so rude to my friend who was asking a
Simple question on how to store bread was met with a shrug. The other customers had to step up to answer questions.

Is this the vibe of this place?
author: Bhadri V.

description: That avocado toast though....  so decadent and flavorful, one full perfectly ripe avocado on toast with thick salt flakes.  I don't care that I'll never afford a house in the Bay Area, this toast makes me happy.
author: Jamie B.

description:
Did you know Provender was listed in Zagat's Top 10 Under-the-radar Restaurants in the Bay? Seriously, Google it. This place has a new cult-following for its food and drinks. But I know what you're thinking, in a city that boasts so many amazing cafès and restaurants, how does Provender even stand out? Two things.

First thing. Their toast. When you go to Provender you absolutely have to try the avocado toast. I don't care if you don't understand the avocado hype, please you need to understand. It's more than just the perfectly ripened avocado... It's the toasty multigrain bread, it's the garlic aioli sauce, it's the fried garlic flakes, it's the cracked black pepper, and of course it's also the fresh cilantro... it's all of this and more. Seriously, this is the only avocado toast that makes sense. Oh and try the trout and dill toast too, heck try all the toast. ALL THE TOAST! 

Second thing. Their coffee. Maple cold brew is the way to go. It's the right amount of sweet with a subtly smoky flavor. They use Andytown coffee here so you know it's good. Grab a stamp card and get free stuff, too.

So there. I'm hoping you get the message. Yes? Yes!!! Provender is now on your radar whenever you're up in Potrero Hill.
author: Noimee L.

description: All the goodness wrapped up in a like 10 feet of customer space. I don't care, there's a little bench to enjoy my coffee and avocado toast. I wish I tried other things, but I dream of the avocado toast. So what it's trendy, this one is worth it. It's different. Trust me.
author: Amy O.

description:
Very cute coffee shop. Coffee and pastry were both great. Service was really nice. Limited seating.

Would go back if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Charles C.

description:
Service was good. The place was cute and clean. Really like this place. Can you open one in the Marina? 
**Almond Milk Latte - Was amazing. Tasted great. That perfect coffee taste. Andytown Coffee. 
**Avocado Toast - Was the best I had. - avocado, cilantro, salt, fried onions and oil. Was so good. MUST TRY!!

Why a 4 star instead of 5? Because I wasn't sure what my coffee art was. Maybe the barista was still learning? But I know they fancy up the coffees here. Only because I know they can do better. I will definitely be coming back because I'm now a fan. And everything was delicious!
author: Sandy B.

description: This place is awesome! I was told about it from Cincinnati OH. I was here on vacation and could have spent all day here. The conversation with staff was great and the coffee was amazing. You'll never find another coffee shop that has staff, that care more about their customers and their coffee. I'll be going back for sure.
author: Alex S.

description:
Avocado toast $10: my favorite in SF! Seedy bread is chewy with a crispy crust, loads of avocado with garlic aioli, fried garlic, lemon juice, cilantro, sesame seeds, and flaky salt... Such a great combo! At first I was surprised at the level of saltiness, but along with the lemon, it cuts through the creaminess and I liked it more and more after each bite. If I live closeby, I would want to come here for this all the time!

Almond butter-banana toast $8: topped with honey and flaky salt. This was a bit too salty for me, but it's really good too!! The almond butter is amazzzing. Same bread as the avocado toast is used, so it was delicious.

Coffee Drinks- American and almond milk latte. Both were yum. I love Andytown coffee, which is what they serve.

The shop is cute, but small. There are two stools available to sit at the window where a small counter is. Three people were seated there (one couple shared one stool) when we were there. They were eating avocado toast and drinking coffee. The menu says Food To Go but I guess they are fine if you eat there too. 

FYI- Didn't see a restroom available for customers. Mainly to-go business I think. Petition available at counter for you to sign to help support a park let for them!
author: Iris H.

description:
The scones here are amazing. For some reason, local bakeries score a "total fail" in their attempts to recreate this British Delicacy. The scones at Provender, however are a total success. 
TEN STARS!!
author: Michael M.

description:
This cafe is a cute little shop located in Potrero. It's close enough to Plow that you can come here and grab a cup of coffee while you wait for a seat at Plow. I attempted to run from my friend's apartment to Provender after a filling meal the night before because it seemed "so close" but SF's hills killed me. Spoiler: I did not make it far by running. So I decided to walk around the neighborhood before stopping here and trying their coffee and avocado toast.

Unfortunately, THEY WERE OUT OF AVOCADOS! I came here on a Monday morning. They ran out of avocados on Sunday night. Alas, no avocado toast for me. I settled for the almond butter and banana toast. It was ok. Pretty dry, but I guess it was expected.

Additionally, they were also out of the maplewood cold brew iced coffee I wanted to try. This day was just not my day. All these hills for nothing!

The only bright spot was that they had a beautiful bouquet of flowers by the window, so I got an Instagram-worthy picture of my latte and almond butter and banana toast.
author: Esther W.

description:
Definitely a fan!

I'm a fan of the avocado toast only because there's no way I could replicate it. Isn't that the point? We go to restaurants to try dishes that we can't just whip up at home and for me, Provender does that really well. THE SECRET? Garlic aioli. I think it makes all the difference and the toppings don't hurt either. And I like that the avocado isn't mashed, but chunks on top of the bread. Definitely makes for a prettier photo ;)

Coffee (I tried the cold brew of course) is solid and is definitely well within SF prices (and even other city's prices). Good brew, not too strong actually.

If it weren't for the parking (tip: park near the playground/tennis court and walk over!) and indoor space, this would totally be a 5-star.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
Tiny place, very expensive, but well worth it. Their cranberry scones are so loaded with butter that they taste like cookies. Deeeelicious!

Scone + latte = $8.25.
author: Kristen S.

description: I think this coffee shop is a gem. I've been on the search for great coffee and been to virtually every coffee shop in SF and this makes my top three. The Maplewood cold brew was delicious and the cappuccino had a great roast, and was really delicious. The winner for the day was the avocado toast, which was sumptuous. They put these bits of garlic on top which blew me away. I'd give them 6 on 5 if I could.
author: Shashank C.

description:
Nice little coffee and breakfast spot in Potrero. Decided to come here for a quick coffee and some food before heading in to work. But it doesn't open until 8!! Seems kinda late for a coffee spot, especially on weekdays when people need to head in to work and it takes at least half an hour to get to downtown from this location. But at least it's right next to the inbound 10 and 22 buses. 

It's pretty small so there's only bar seating with three stools inside and I think a bench outside. The decor is nice and classy- what you would expect from a third wave coffee shop in the city. 

Tried the quick cup coffee that's around two dollars. It's not bad- but also not amazing. 

Their toast is quite pricey. But sound so good! The avocado toast sounds bomb, but it's ten dollars. I know it's SF, but dammmmmmmmn. Opted to try the almond butter, banana, honey and sea salt toast ("only" $8). Presentation is FANTASTIC (see photo).  It is served on a Heath plate. Taste was disappointing :( The bread is really good- thick slice and comes out warm. I think it's from PAIN bakery- not sure where that is, but they specially point out the bread origin on their menu, so I assume it's one of the bougie, popular bakeries that are overpriced, overcrowded, but damn delicious in the city (or elsewhere in the Bay Area). Overall, though, the dish is too sal- the sea salt was overpowering because the honey wasn't very sweet and the almond butter was not at all sweet. I think it would have balanced better if they used sweeter honey to counteract the saltiness of the sea salt. 

Cool that they have a stamp card! Buy ten drinks and get one free- and if you flip to the other side, it's buy ten get one free for sandwiches and toast. We saw the scones come right out of the oven and they looked super tasty- must try next time!
author: Josephine L.

description: I had a pleasant, peaceful time reading my book in this cute little coffee shop. There's only about 6 seats but I was the only one at the time sitting down so it worked. I love the fact that it's a 10 minute walk from my apartment too and it's located in an upcoming area. The latte I ordered was fresh and smooth, and watching the barista make it so effortlessly was like an art. He also killed a bee for me that was flying around my head like a hero. I would love to come back here again
author: Elizabeth G.

description: I found a gem in my neighborhood a couple weeks ago.  I've kept coming back. Love all the details in this little space. I love avocado toast and found their avocado toast is extraordinary. I think the bread and the seasoning they used to make avocado toast have a special kick. Absolutely a winner.  An awesome spot in Potrero Hill to chill out and enjoy people watching.
author: Shell J.

description: I am a huge fan of the espresso drinks at Provender.  Their coffee is always top notch, and they have pretty solid food as well.
author: Ross E.

description: Provender's toast is AMAZING and the staff are super nice as well. I usually get the avocado toast, and the crispy garlic & olive oil combo really makes it stand above other avo toasts I've had. Their tea & coffee are a strong point too of course, and I can recommend the matcha specifically. Finally, the benches they have out front are really nice to sit on while enjoying your food--though remember to bring a jacket.
author: Maximilian B.

description: Delightful neighborhood coffee shop and cafe. The staff are friendly, the coffee is good, and the decor lovely. What more could you want?
author: Cecilia C.

description:
Great drip coffee
Great smoked salmon
Bunch of other places just like it all along that street
Parking was easy
Friendly staffers
She got chia pudding, which was alright
And some gf pastry. They have a few of those
author: Parker L.

description:
Cute, teeny-tiny coffee shop with a 2-3 bar stools inside and a bench outside. 
We had the Maple Cold Brew which I read about on the SF's coffee heat map. We thought it'd be like maple-flavored/enhanced coffee notes, but it tasted WAY too sweet as if mounds of maple syrup was stirred in. My husband has NEVER tossed a cup of coffee away unfinished but it had to go after a few sips. To each their own, and if u like super sweet coffee than you may like it!
I had the 'Lichee Red tea'. I should've guessed that if they couldn't spell Lychee right it probably wasn't going to taste like Lychee. It just tasted like red tea.
Heat map you've failed me this time!
author: Sharon H.

description:
Provender is one of my absolute favorite local eateries for cookies and salads. Yes, that's right fellow Yelpers, notice I did not say coffee. While I am sure their coffee is wonderful, I am actually not a coffee drinker.  I went to this establishment because I saw the lovely blue decor and wanted to support a new local establishment in the Bay Area. 

The sea salt chocolate-chip cookie is delicious. The outside is crisp and  perfectly browned with a slightly doughy center. The cookie is very large so it's definitely a dessert that can be shared by two people or eaten by one lucky cookie lover. 

The quinoa saiad is also a top pick of mine as the quinoa is paired with almonds, olives, feta, currants, and spinach. The salad is incredibly flavorful and a nice detox from a week of eating heavier foods. 

Beyond the food, what keeps me coming back is the staff. The staff members are extremely friendly and work hard to prep the food in the open kitchen behind the counter.
author: Dawn B.

description: The best hipster coffee in Potrero (they serve Andytown). Sans pretentiousness, this is a cheerful neighborhood spot to fuel up.
author: Anita L.

description: The macchiato is pretty good & smooth. I love this cozy spot. This is the perfect coffee shop in Portrero Hill. I went here when I was waiting for Plow and I'm so thankful for them. They definitely enhanced that waiting experience ;)
author: Jenna L.

description: I just discovered this cafe a couple weeks ago, and I was already calling it "my new cafe," but when I stopped by today at 2:40pm - 20 minutes before closing - the girl at the counter had already cleaned up and saw fit to completely ignore me. After I stood there waiting awhile she looked at me and didn't even say hello. What horrible customer service.
author: Gabriela F.

description: The best toast I've ever eaten. Super cute sitting area, and nice location. I'm from Detroit, and I found this place on yelp. The people that work there were so friendly. I also had the wood maple cold brew, it was good, however, I should have got a hot coffee, since it was so cold this morning.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
The folks at Plow sent us here during our two hour wait for a brunch table (worth it), which gave us time for a pre breakfast at Provender. 

My friend got a latte, I got the maple cold brew, and both were some of the best coffee I've had in this coffee town. Delicious flavor, not too much acid, really playful maple syrup notes in the cold brew. A nice option for someone who wants sweeter coffee.

We also got the avocado bacon toast and the goat cheese and herb biscuits. Both were phenomenal, but if you're headed to plow, opt for the smaller (and absolutely delectable) biscuit. I grew up in the south with a baker for a mother. I know a good biscuit when I see one. This was some next level biscuit shit.

In other words: don't miss it!!
author: Celie H.

description:
I came here with a friend on Saturday morning while we were waiting to get seated at Plow, and I must say, I thoroughly enjoyed my experience at Provender much more!

We both ordered lattes and shared an order of the almond butter and banana toast. The staff was super friendly and highly recommended the avocado toast, but my sweet tooth was calling for the almond butter that morning. The lattes were excellent! A perfect start to the morning and delicious. The toast came as a thick slab smothered with a generous amount of almond butter, covered with banana slices and drizzled with honey. It was delicious as well! It was both sweet and a little savory.

Provender Coffee and Food is such a little neighborhood gem! I will definitely be back to try the maple cold brew and the avocado toast.
author: Cheryl N.

description:
Their maple cold brew is out of this world. 

Stumbled upon this place recently when I was waiting for brunch and craving coffee. Boy did I make the right decision. After ordering and tasting this heavenly drink, i realized that this was a cold brew I had heard of multiple times and had been meaning to try for the past year or so. UN-FREAKING-REAL.

Need to go back and try their toasts. They all look delicious.
author: Ilana B.

description: This is probably my favorite avocado toast in town but the wait was way too long. I waited for 25+ mins just to get the toast. Latte is pretty standard. Friendly staff if you know them at a personal level. The outdoor bench is a plus..
author: Kevi O.

description: Great coffee. Great food, roasts are amazing. Great people. This place is truly a gem.
author: Aleks M.

description: If you're looking for a hip place and to enjoy something simple on a late Saturday morning, come here. Personally, I think this place is overpriced but the quality is pretty good. A mocha and an avocado toast came to about 16$, which is really pricey, but both were very tasty. I definitely never will pay 10$ for an avocado toast again, but it was a good experience and the staff and the atmosphere were nice.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: A solid spot to caffeinate while waiting for a table at Plow.  Drip coffee was good, but too bad that pour overs aren't offered.  Service was average at best and the place itself is miniscule, so best to grab and go.
author: Eric F.

description:
Reducing to 4 stars.  Why?  I feel they're getting a little greedy.

A couple months ago they changed their POS system so instead of % based tipping options for coffee it's now $1/2/3 by default.  I consider myself a good tipper but think it's a little obnoxious to suggest I should be tipping a MINIMUM of 25% for a pretty basic $4 drink.  

They also raised the price of their cold brew to $4.25.  It's really small but since it's so good that's fine with me.  What's not fine with me is a splash of almond milk went up to 75 cents.  That's annoying since an entire bottle is $1.99 at Whole Foods.

I've gotten into a habit of going here about twice a week but given the changes one of my New Years resolutions is to cut that down big time.
author: george c.

description:
Stopped by while waiting for brunch at Plow. I had the Gibraltar (two shots of espresso with whole milk) and thought it was average. I tried my friend's mocha latte and could hardly taste the mocha.  Anyway, if you need caffeine this is a slightly overpriced way to get it. 

The wait was a little long -- there are two guys manning all responsibilities: the barista also does the register and the other gentleman works on the culinary creations. So I waited about 10 minutes with 2 people in front of me. I liked the location and vibes of this place though! I wouldn't be against wandering back here while on another brunch wait.
author: Julia Y.

description: This was a fantastic little coffee shop.  Delicious coffee, extremely cute interior, nice space outside to sit, and great pastries.
author: Laleh J.

description: As a girl of simple tastes, this place was too much for me. I prefer a diner breakfast - bacon, eggs, toast for $10. Instead I came here and got two slices of avocado toast for $10. While it wasn't terrible, it was too "gourmet" for me with the garlic aioli, cilantro, black sesame, and various other toppings. They definitely did not skimp on the avocado either - there was plenty in each mouthful, in fact I found myself wishing there was more bread in each bite. I paired my toast with a $2.50 drip coffee, which was self-serve and pretty flavorful. The blend I chose listed flavors of buttered toast and peat. My boyfriend thought it just tasted like dirt. If you like cute, bougie food and decor then you will love this place! Its not a bad place by any means, just not my cup of tea. After eating what felt like an entire avocado I found myself wishing I had some eggs or bacon to round out the meal. I recommend this place to anyone who loves a good avocado toast made right in front of you!
author: Sara S.

description:
Provender's avocado toast is the best in the city. No question. It's pricey, but so is every avo toast in SF....

Their coffee is always balanced and right on point and the staff is so friendly and unpretentious. 

I love coming here weekdays, weekends, whatever. If you're in a rush or rude, please don't waste their (or my) time - they make their coffee/food with love and that can take more than 2 minutes.
author: Francesca F.

description:
Avocado toast. Definitely order this even if you don't think you're much of an avocado fan cause this particular toast at Provender was too good to pass up. 

The chili flakes sprinkled on top with creamy mayonnaise is a combination I'm definitely adding to my own kitchen recipe for avocado toast. A tad too salty for me, so if you do order it, ask for less salt! 

My iced latte was quite refreshing too, nothing too special but delicious nonetheless. I want to try their pour over at my next visit!
author: Kristi L.

description: Coffee is mediocre and overpriced. I'd rather get McDonald's coffee, which tastes better and cheaper. What more can I say?
author: Dan K.

description:
This little coffee shop is a nice addition to the stretch of establishments on 18th St. in Potrero. It's a tiny place, so don't expect to be able to sit down and eat: there's a small bar along the window with 2 seats, so you can probably perch and eat for a little bit if there's room. Otherwise, there's one bench outside.

They have some of the best coffee in the city - with a wide variety of choices: latte, americano, cappucino, gibraltar, mocha, and more, and teas if that's more of your thing. My only gripe was that for the price ($4 for a latte), it came in miniature cup. I felt like I was drinking out of a child's sippy cup. You can't select the size of your drink, so you're stuck paying a lot of money for a small amount of coffee.

They have a decent food selection for such a small place that has such a strong coffee focus, with a few healthy options. We opted for avocado toast ($8), which comes on a thick slab of rye toast, and basically an entire avocado placed on top of each half of toast. It's sprinkled with garlic bits, salt, and black sesame and it's delicious. I still love Jane's (on Fillmore or Larkin) avocado toast more, but this is still pretty good.

The salad ($8) seems to be seasonal, and the one I had was wheat berries, squash, olives, almonds, and capers. It was really good - a bit on the small side, but tasty and healthy. Add a sous vide egg for $2, and it's a great addition (to pretty much anything)

They also have baked goods that seem to run $3-4 a pop: chocolate chip cookies, black sesame banana bread, scones, that I'll have to try some time. They also have 2 sandwiches to choose from.

Overall, a solid coffee & food place in Potrero, and probably one of the better in the neighborhoods. But for the price and the size of the items, I have to knock off one star. I still prefer my staples like Jane or Reville Coffee for good food & coffee.
author: Christina L.

description:
Yes yes... I too will rave about the Avocado Toast only because it really is worth raving about.
The avacoado is garnished with Corriander and sesame that just adds tiny explosions of tastes when you bite into the bread that is toasted to perfection.
But being a fish lover I totally dug their Trout & Dill toast too. 
A super friendly neighbourhood vibe in this teeny-tiny shop will make for a great Sunday brunch.
author: Nandini B.

description:
Came here for a quick bite since there was a LONG wait at Plow. This is a tiny shop, but it's so good! Service was great - the guy was really knowledgeable about what they offered.

I tried the avocado toast and it was AMAZING!!! You get 1.5 slices topped with avocado, cilantro, salt and oil. It was so refreshing and filling! This is a must have if you like avocado toast! The bf had a cappuccino and said it was good. Quality items!

The only downside is that there are only two seats at the bar since it's a small place. However, there are benches outside and we ate our toast there.

Oh, and the pastries and other foods are made on-site! They looked really good too. Def come try this place!
author: Lillian C.

description:
Avocadooooooo toast is so simple yet tasty here. Love the garlic aioli added to their toast to give it extra flavor. Made to perfection and highly recommend trying it out. 

As for the drinks, I ordered an iced chai latte and my boyfriend ordered a macchiato. I wasn't much of a fan of my beverage. Tasted a bit watered down and it came in a tiny cup.. 

The place is very intimate with only two seats inside (ordering is made for to go) and a couple benches outside. Parking is also street so be sure to bring walking shoes just in case!
author: Irene O.

description: A coffee place with no artificial sweeteners?  Yes, that's right, screw you if your a diabetic!  I will be sure and stay away from this place!
author: Chip Y.

description:
Love this little neighborhood coffee shop. $10 may seem steep for avocado toast, but it's worth it! I also loved the maple cold brew. I'm not a huge coffee drinker, so this was easy and delicious for me to sip on. 

Not a ton of inside seating, just some bar stools. More of a grab and go type of place versus a loungey coffee shop. Staff is super nice and friendly too. 

Will definitely stop by again next time I'm in the area.
author: Lindsey C.

description:
The husband and I were leaving to drive down the big sur for a couple of days and needed a quick coffee fix. This cute looking coffee shop was on our way, so we ditched our normal go-to Chats cafe to try it. I ordered two cold brew maple coffees to go and then proceeded to be confused by what happened next. 

For $4 each, I was served two tiny (tiny!!!!) cups of cold brew on ice in TINY paper cups. There was a great precision to the preparation of this coffee.. with the ice weighed out before the coffee was poured. Given that we had a drive ahead of us, I transferred the coffees into cold cups, and each only took up a third of the space. I paid and left, confused and wondering how this was ok. Maybe I'm just not used to how cool this is supposed to be, and while the coffee was tasty, maybe I'm just not San Francisco enough to appreciate three sips of coffee for $4. Too hipster for me or something like that.
author: Archana P.

description: I almost walked right by this place. That would have been a huge mistake. The coffee is great, and the small food selection is fantastic. I highly recommend the sous vide egg toast and the almond cake.
author: Drew C.

description:
So, I am surprised by the 5 star reviews. I came in a month back and have been meaning to write this review. Maybe I just ordered the wrong thing here, but I was hugely disappointed. Do not order an iced latte and expect to actually have anything to drink. My iced latte was served in a tiny, and I mean Barbie dream house tiny, paper cup. Which essentially left me with a sip of lukewarm coffee that I paid $4 for. Was it good? I don't know because there wasn't enough of it to even tell. 

I also was convinced to buy the avocado toast. They seriously pushed the toast. Now, I love me some avocado toast. I took it to go otherwise I would have complained directly too them. Again, maybe I ordered wrong here, but there was so much garlic I could not eat it. Does the menu say it has garlic, yes, but I didn't think it would be enough to ward off all vampires in the world. 

Essentially, I walked out with an overpriced sip of coffee and food I couldn't eat. I seriously took a bite of the toast and was ill.
author: Thompson M.

description: Walking into Provender feels super special right away. It's TINY, and you have to be a little patient, but the space is cool and they're making everything with love so it's worth the wait. The avocado toast is the best I've ever had. Like an incredible layered flavor bomb on the most perfect bread ever, and the portion is pretty big. The coffee is smooth and delicious, both hot and iced. I will never spend time in San Francisco without stopping in here.
author: Faith K.

description:
Black sesame banana bread wins all the prizes. And the cold brew is magic.

These guys are up to good stuff. Come check out this great new neighborhood spot.
author: who k.

description: I walked up the hill to check this place out. The baristas were both extremely friendly and knowledgeable. I decided to go with the maple cold brew and sesame banana bread: both delicious. The cold brew, at least for me, was perfect as is and did not need any additional sugar. The banana bread was denser than expected but flavorful and filling. Yum!
author: Joyce O.

description:
Attribute it to the plethora of good to amazing restaurants in Potrero Hill, but I'll never find myself going hungry (or more likely, hangry) around the four blocks that surround Provender. As it turns out, I'm always in the neighborhood with a restaurant already in mind, so unfortunately for them (and for myself), an after-meal Sightglass coffee is all I can foresee myself procuring from this shoe box-sized coffee shop. 

Their iced Americano with almond milk is delicious, mild, and refreshing; no extra sugar needed. Their Gibralter (kind of like a latte except the milk isn't mixed in, I think) is also hella good. Twice, the same cute, young barista made my drinks & I'm thinking he's got magic in them hands; never a bitter, burnt, or weak drink has passed my lips since I met him. 

Damn it. If Provender's coffee tastes this good, I know I'm missing out on their Avocado Toast & Arugula Salad.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Nice quaint coffee spot. Staff is friendly and there's about 5 seats to hang for a bit. They also have good bites, avocado toast and sandwiches.
author: Erica E.

description:
Provender satisfied my craving for a mid morning snack and espresso with effortless expertise. They take the concept of gourmet toast to the next level with multi-layered flavors and fresh ingredients. 

Milk foam skills were on point for my cappuccino and everyone seemed like they genuinely loved what they were doing. Simple decor and mellow music created a good vibe. Check it out.
author: Matt L.

description:
Went there today for the first time, tried their 
Maple wood cold brew, banana bread and one chocolate chip cookie. All I can say is get the blue haired girl to serve you. Great coffee, great service.
author: Bernardina A.

description: Super cute hipster cafe with super limited (as in 2-3 stools inside, 1 bench outside) seating that serves Sightglass coffee and insanely good pastries. Next, I will try their avocado toast or maybe the sous vide eggs toast.
author: Helen F.

description: I really liked the decor, but the space was kinda tiny. The coffee was dece. The avo toast was yum but too expensive
author: Regina J.

description: Tiny little location with big flavors, and delicious food. My cousin and I stopped by and grabbed some almond milk lattes, and banana poppyseed bread. Fabulous staff, welcoming and friendly. The rest of the menu will definitely be explored by us in the near future.
author: Ilyssa R.

description: Had the maple wood cold brew. Not my taste, but cute shop and awesome help. Really adorable black french bulldog visitor.
author: Fernilla S.

description:
We Dogpatch-Potrero folk are downright spoiled when it comes to designer coffee joints...dare I say, this is what sold this self-proclaimed coffee snob on moving into the 'hood. 

I live right next door to the big Philz HQ location (which is great), but I've been known to hop in my car to get my java and foodie treats fix at Provender. I just tried the goat cheese-stuffed bacon biscuit this morning...and let me tell you, it was the stuff of legends! YFY!
author: Melanie D.

description: Stopped in here for some coffee while my friend and I waited for a table at Plow. We both got the maple wood cold brew ($4 each) and it was deeeelicious. I normally add some sort of sweetener to my coffees, but I didn't have to with this one. It was so smooth. Just what we needed to get us through the wait at plow. :)
author: Taylor W.

description:
They used to have delicious food and now they don't.
Big disappointment.
It is not worth the $10!
Go to Hazels or Farleys down the street.
author: Alyssa E.

description:
Provender was the very first establishment that I visited while visiting SF. I was greeted by Christopher, a self proclaimed gregarious character. Both the Gibralter and the Scarlett iced tea were fantastic, and Christopher made our experience there not only fun and entertaining, but an extremely memorable first impression of the city. 
Highly recommended.
author: Corin T.

description:
When Baked closed in this location, I was so sad. Then, when I heard a new coffee shop was opening in its place, I was disappointed. Really? Another trendy, probably overpriced coffee shop? We already have Chat's and Farley's all within one block. 

Then I actually went in. Not only are the employees very friendly and polite, but their coffee is the best I've had in the city. Provender is now one of my favorite spots in Potrero - I haven't even been to another coffee shop since. Their food is great too. Love it!
author: Cory D.

description:
A new spot in the 'hood. Got the banana bread and the chai latte. Definitely on the pricier side of things but the stuff was very good. As a chai snob, I am always running into cinnamon heavy versions but this one had the right mix of the spices in the chai. The space itself is very small but the benches outsides and the parklet a block over are convenient sit down + people watching spots. 

Between this place, Farley's and the Philz down the street, Potrero seems to have come alive with a good mix of coffee/tea places.
author: Rahul H.

description: This new teeny tiny shop was a little hard to find since it seems to have a chameleon characteristics in blending in with some of the other shops on the block.  That being said, upon finding it, I was overwhelmed with what I should order.  Without doing too much internet consultation, and after being offered a sample of a chocolate chip cookie Provender is looking to offer, I decided on the Maple Wood Cold Brew.  Much to my surprise, the cold brew isn't served black but rather with some milk, maple syrup, and maple extract (hence the "maple"... ::light bulb flashes::).  While I'm generally not a sweet coffee person, this was actually incredibly delicious, so I'm almost glad that I went into this without too much knowledge since I know it's something I wouldn't have ordered had I known what goes into it.  Sightglass is the name game here, and they've got a number of delicious looking pastries for sale as well.  The guys working behind the counter were incredibly nice and welcoming (which isn't always a guarantee this days). If it weren't for the somewhat complicated parking situation in the neighborhood, I would definitely make a habit out of coming here!
author: Lisa I.

description: Outstanding cold brew hazel. The shop has good vibes and energy. My friends had chai lattes and a scone. We enjoyed our drinks and time there! Returning back today!
author: Casey V.

description: Very cute shop, clean, and inviting in a great neighborhood. Friendly staff and a nice selection of coffee drinks, teas, and food. Was thrilled to see they had a gf almond cake! Coffee beans from Andytown Coffee Roasters. The cold brew is excellent. Their hot drip coffee has a strong citrus finish which I don't care for. Would totally recommend. Next time I'm trying their chai!
author: Stacey A.

description:
Come for the cookie, not for the drinks. 

Granted I didn't have a coffee drink... I went for the chai latte. My girlfriend got a hot chocolate. Both were lacking strong flavors. My chai latte tasted watered down, not frothy and creamy the way I like. The hot chocolate tasted of dark chocolate, which I actually like, but it unfortunately was also a watered down version of what it should be. 

But the chocolate chip cookie definitely made up for it. They even warmed it up for us. It was greasy, crispy on the edges, soft in the middle, top with a little sea salt. Nom nom nom :)
author: Melyssa A.

description:
My new favorite in the neighborhood :)  Aside from the coffee being great, the staff at Provender are a great bunch whom I always enjoy seeing.  Austin especially is a familiar face from the times I enjoy dinners at Hillside Supper Club and is always great to speak with.

Provender is what a true espresso bar should be IMO.  You go in get your cafe to drink at the bar and enjoy a chat, pastry and be on your way.  Of course they do have to-go cups if you need that Cappuccino for your walk/drive to work :)  They also branch out a bit and offer an eclectic menu of food items like Avocado Toast and Leg of Lamb Sando.  I particularly enjoy the Bacon, Goat Cheese & Green Onion biscuit.

I plan on Provender being a part of my weekly routine from now on!
author: Ed F.

description: Awesome staff and amazing coffee and food. Avocado toast is $10 but delicious. You know the place is good when lots of locals are going there.
author: David M.

description: I've tried avocado toast at the Samovar Tea Bar, the Richfield, Coffee Bar, Nourish Cafe, Cafe St. Jorge, JANE, and at As Quoted. Hands down this place makes the best avocado toast I've ever had. Every single ingredient they used was YUMMY and the garlic flakes on top just crush it. I appreciate that they load it up with the avocado and use a big piece of bread...other places really skimp on that stuff. The shop itself is small with 3 chairs for seating inside and a couple benches outside. I'll definitely be back to try their other menu offerings.
author: Ashley M.

description: Traveling to San Fran for a week & this was by far the best coffee I found in the city. It's true, their maple wood cold brew is awesome, but they also had the best Italian cappuccino. Perfectly roasted & perfectly creamy. I miss it already.
author: Ashley B.

description: My mocha was fine, too bitter for my taste but I understand to each their own. Banana bread is acceptable but both are over-priced and the quantities are too small.
author: Matt A.

description:
Came in to check out the highly recommended avocado toast. A little steep but so so good. I got a masala chai. Love it because it's not sweet like most chai beverages.  A neighborhood gem!

I wish there is this type of cafe in my hood!
author: Mei S.

description: ok, yes this is a small place but the coffee is delicious.  I went for the standard drip coffee, didn't try a coffee drink. Sesame seed banana bread was worth it even though I'm not sure that the seeds made a difference in the flavor from standard banana bread.  It is hard to spot from the street and you could easily drive right by it.
author: K L.

description: One of my absolute favorite tiny hidden cafes in the city, tucked away in Potrero Hill. I've come here 3x now for some seriously good lattes. The space is about the size of a closet, but it's simply beautiful with monochrome tile flooring and fresh flowers. Love the vibe, and I also highly recommend their avocado toast!
author: Lauren N.

description:
I was passing through my old neighbourhood today when I noticed a new coffee shop. Feeing adventurous, I went in for a cappuccino. While waiting, I noticed the sign on the door and realised that today is the first day it has been open!

Despite my initial worries due to the newness of the setup, the coffee was great. I came back for a second coffee later in fact. I didn't try the bakes but they smelled good. Both coffees were consistent in quality. 

I'm really glad to see more espresso focussed coffee shops :)
author: Bo J.

description: straight up the best avo toast i've ever had. the evoo and lemon touches on it makes it so frickin good. i would eat another right now
author: Chelsea P.

description:
Good espresso made here. They use proper technique that puts them in the "true San Francisco quality coffee" category for me. They don't serve decaf, which is amusing and fair enough I guess. They use coffee from Sightglass.

The brewed coffee they make is actually pretty good, even though it is made in bulk.

I'd recommend going to this place for a quick espresso or espresso-based drink. There is not a lot of room to sit, but the coffee is tasty.
author: Jake N.

description: Worst service ever! The coffee guys are rude. First they don't give you what you order and then they treat you like Sh... when you remind them what your order was. And it is super expensive!
author: Anne H.

description: A hidden treasure :)  Stumbled in with a desperate need for coffee and it was phenomenal. Was intrigued by the avocado toast with a sous vide egg and was not disappointed. I loved the rustic bread they used (crispy crunch!). Overall an amazing experience.
author: Risa G.

description: Great coffee. Rare roaster with a flavorful blend. Cafe is unique and the edibles are gorgeous l. Alas, no gluten free. Would rate the place higher but every time I've gone, they are playing screaming multi-swear word rap music, watched many a parent walk in and quickly walk their kids out!!!
author: Sergio M.

description: Great coffee. Limited choice of pastry but since this the first day I'll cut them some slack. Would be nice to have some benches outside. Great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Jeffrey O.

description:
tasty but overpriced. my beau and I got a ham and cheese toast and I swore I ordered a bacon and goat cheese biscuit but was delivered a cherry scone. the coffee was indeed very good- maplewood cold brew, but not worth $4 for a tiny cup. 

very friendly service and glad we tried it but not worth the price tag.
author: Nora C. E.

description: Chef Dan is the man. I trust him with my life. His culinary genius is felt in each tantalizing bite. Provender can do no wrong.
author: Steve K.

description: Great little nook, with delightful servers! Masala Chai latte, it was Very creamy, and smooth.  Avacado toast is so amazing! This toast is a must!
author: Tara M.

description: The cookies are every bit as amazing as the reviews said they'd be. Perfect spot on a rainy day to find warm coffee freshly brewed. Very non chain, which is delightful.
author: Marissa W.

description: As good as it gets. Their coffee is incredible (try the maple iced), their food is insane (try the avocado toast) and their take home are unbeatable (try the almond butter). Local guys with a local shop. Support them!
author: Anthony G.

description: Super Friendly staff , nice strong latte - definitely return in future . Nice quiet spot to stare out the window and sip a cup of mocha.
author: Sheldon G.

description: We love Provender. The guys are all very welcoming and friendly.  Most importantly the Capps and Espressi are yum!
author: Alicia F.

description:
I am very particular about my coffee and am delighted with this new addition to the neighborhood. I am mostly a drip / brew drinker , but it's my experience that if a place can do an excellent simple cup of plain coffee with no sugar / dairy to cover the flaws, it bodes well for all their espresso drinks, and that has certainly proven to be the case for Provender.

As for the venue, I am hoping this kind of business is the right "fit" for this kind of shoebox space. It is really for someone who wants superior coffee and a light, artisanal bite to go.
author: Ruth m.

description:
Cute cafe with good coffee, good pastries, and friendly staff. Very happy this opened in the neighborhood! I'd HIGHLY recommend their black sesame banana bread. That is just inspired.

By the way, this place is really small with no seating, so it's more of a to-go kind of cafe. Good place to meet up with people or get coffee on your way to work; not a good place for hanging out for hours.
author: Morgane M.

description: Great spot on Potrero Hill.  Excellent, friendly service, very nice looking space. Austin, Tony, Alex, Aran, & David know their coffee & baked goods. It was great watching the baked good being made in-house. Perfect latte, & a morning bun. Delicious!  Definitely worth the trip. You go there for a nice break, you leave as friends!
author: Pam R.

description: Cute place for a quick coffee and cookies. Friendly staff
author: Marie r.

description: Consistently bomb cappuccino and their iced coffee lives up to the hype. This is a great spot for a light lunch. Most if not all of the menu items bring out new flavors in your coffee so be sure to grab some food. Even the freshly made quinoa spinach almond salad complemented my drink quite well.
author: Deb L.

description: This place was really bad. I came in to order and the two guys were chatting to each other and some other customer and ignored us for what felt awkwardly long so I felt like walking out. It was kinda bro-ey and they had really loud music so it felt like I was not welcome and it was a bit intimidating tbh. I asked for a chai latte and then asked if it could be iced and the barista seemed a bit cagey but said yes thats fine.I said if you don't do it its no problem but then he said no no its fine I will do it. I felt really stupid. So I waited at the bench and then after 10 mins I tried to make eye contact since about 5 people got served after me. Eventually the guy looked over at me and said "Oh right yeah was I meant to be making something for you?" and I told him my order again but I felt like saying "Yeah thats what the money I gave you 10 mins ago was for". He didn't seem sorry at all and I just felt like asking to cancel it so I could leave. After 5 mins he shouted my drink and then just turned away and I said "Thanks" and left. After 15 mins I thought at least I got my drink. But the chai wasn't even spicy! It tasted like plastic mixed with milk. It was so bad I threw it away. The whole experience was awful. I will never be back. I just hate these hipster places who make you feel like a total a-hole just for existing and trying to give them money in exchange for services. At farleys you feel welcome and valued always so just walk on by and go to farleys.
author: Bla B.

description: Our Gibraltars were either burnt or the milk was off. Disappointing as the place is really cute and the menu looks lovely. We'd driven off too far to turn back and get our coffees changed.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Cute place
came here thinking I'd treat myself to a Gibralter coffee (expresso with warm milk), and it was so sour, and puckery. I couldn't drink it. I asked if the milk was maybe off, but it did not appear to be, anyway they offered to make me something else, so i asked for just an espresso, can't go wrong there, but no, that was the culprit!! It was so so sour, and puckery, i mean, just terrible. I thought of the emperor with no clothes on and maybe the joke was on me, but i could not go along with it and drink it, it was just awful. If coffee tasted like this, i would not drink it. Anyway I did not say anything, as they were so nice in making me another drink, but i poured it out on the street and brought the cute ceramic cup back in. 
I noticed other posts also mentioning terrible bitter (in my case sour) coffee. 
So much for treating myself to a yummy $4 coffee on this fine day.  
I hope this post gets read and that they (owner)seriously considers using a different coffee and/or a different blend, I can't think of anyone that would find it tasty.
author: Diana B.

description: There is clearly a coffee vision here! Everything from the decor to the music to the group of people huddled outside eating on benches makes it hard to resist walking in. Both baristas were helpful, friendly, and thoroughly explained their classic maple wood cold brew. The drink was strong, aromatic, and had a hint of sweetness which was a perfect pick me up on a Sunday morning . Next time we'll check out the homemade baked goods and toast!
author: Shira G.

description: cute little coffee shop with seats for only 3 people. yet if you're lucky to get there before the other 2-3 people you can seat by the window and enjoy the calming,peaceful ambient. they have a variety of food and snacks. interesting pastries. however none of them is really fresh or that yummy. everything is just medium delicious. The size of their cakes are half of what other places usually call a slice and everything is ridiculously expensive, yes even for the city, the prices are higher than other coffee shops, well for what they offer. again the banana bread cake was not that yummy it was just average. the coffee is horribly bad: i wasn't surprised though, everything is kinda dirty in terms of their equipments and surfaces. the baristas were average warm and friendly if not rude for showing me a puzzled faxe for not understanding my accent: i mean i wasn't reading a difficult piece of literature  for her anyways: just something from the menus. wasn't she supposed to be familiar with what is on the menu? anyways, she offered to warm my pastries and that was nice. i would go back of i'm hungry and late and need to get pastries to save time and to fill my stomach.m but i would not get drip coffee from this place no matter how badly my brain would need caffeine.
author: Helia S.

description: Our drinks were average (my husband got an iced latte and I got the lychee red tea), but the service was seriously lacking. The girl who took our order was rude and unhelpful. Apathetically told us the drink we came for (maplewood cold brew) was out, offered no alternative suggestions, and while she was supposed to be taking our order, kept chatting and being very helpful to others in the shop. She was oddly friendly to the folks after us too. Not sure why she couldn't be the same with us. We won't be coming back here again.
author: Sarah L.

description: Maplewood cold brew with almond milk is delicious! Small shop. Wished we got to try some of their toast, but they sold out. Will definitely come again.
author: Ricky W.

description: I got horrible food poisoning from their avocado toast. Gross. How hard is it to wash your hands after you handle money and make some toast?!
author: Michelle m.

description: Have been there 2 days in a row.  Their maple wood cold brew coffee is amazing.  The guys are really friendly.  Will try some lunch soon (Salads and Sandwiches).  The baked goods smelled delicious!
author: Patricia T.

description: food is crap....and staff are so rude....0 stars if possible...no way jose to go back in this sh*t hole.
author: Lenard G.

description: amazing chocolate chip cookies. i have been eating the quinoa spinach salad with bacon and avacado everyday or like 2 weeks straight now. i've lived on the hill for almost 15 years and we have been in dire need of a decent espresso.. i told them to make me a "mochachanno" as a joke and they made me one of the best coffee drinks i've ever had. it's not on the menu though and i made it up so you can't have one. just sayin..
author: Gabriel M.
